questions.question: I did it because I wanted to.
questions.description: An adverb clause of reason is usually introduced by a conjunction like as, since or because.

questions.question: As he was not there, I spoke to his mother.
questions.description: An adverb clause of reason is usually introduced by a conjunction like as, since or because.

questions.question: Just as he entered the room, the clock struck eleven.
questions.description: An adverb clause of time shows the time of the action mentioned in the main clause.

questions.question: If you eat too much you will fall ill.
questions.description: Adverb clauses of condition are usually introduced by the subordinating conjunctions if or unless.

questions.question: We asked him many questions when he returned.
questions.description: An adverb clause of time shows the time of the action mentioned in the main clause.

questions.question: My parents were poor though they were of noble birth.
questions.description: Adverb clauses of concession or contrast are usually introduced by the conjunctions though and although.

questions.question: Mary had a little lamb whose fleece was as white as snow.
questions.description: Here the adjective clause ‘whose fleece was as white as snow’ modifies the noun lamb.

questions.question: I still live in the same city where I was born.
questions.description: Here the adjective clause 'where I was born' modifies the noun city.

questions.question: He met a girl whose eyes were blue.
questions.description: Here the adjective clause whose eyes were blue modifies the noun girl.

questions.question: I often wonder how you are getting on.
questions.description: Here the noun clause ‘how you are getting on’ acts as the object of the verb wonder.

questions.question: He asked me where I lived.
questions.description: Here the noun clause ‘where I lived’ acts as the object of the verb asked.

questions.question: The fact that he is silent proves his guilt.
questions.description: Here the noun clause 'the fact that he is silent' is the object of the verb proves.
